comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @defgroup    drivers_periph_freqm FREQM
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph
+ * @brief       FREQM peripheral driver interface
+ *
+ * This interface allows to configure and use the for Frequency Meter (FREQM)
+ * available on some Microchip Boards.
+ *
+ * The Frequency Meter uses the frequency of a known reference clock to
+ * determine with a 24-bit accuracy the frequency of another clock.
+ *
+ *
+ * @{
+ *
+ * @file
+ * @brief       FREQM peripheral driver interface definitions
+ *
+ * @author      Urs Gompper <urs.gompper@ml-pa.com>
+ */
+
+#ifndef PERIPH_FREQM_H
+#define PERIPH_FREQM_H
+
+#include "periph_cpu.h"
+
+/* Channel Enable Mask */
+#define GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Pos)
+/* Enable Mask */
+#define FREQM_CTRLA_ENABLE_Msk  (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_CTRLA_ENABLE_Pos)
+/* Start Measurement Mask */
+#define FREQM_CTRLB_START_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_CTRLB_START_Pos)
+/* Measurement Done Interrupt Enable Mask */
+#define FREQM_INTENSET_DONE_Msk (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_INTENSET_DONE_Pos)
+/* Measurement Done Mask */
+#define FREQM_INTFLAG_DONE_Msk  (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_INTFLAG_DONE_Pos)
+/* FREQM Status Mask */
+#define FREQM_STATUS_BUSY_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_STATUS_BUSY_Pos)
+/* Sticky Count Value Overflow Mask */
+#define FREQM_STATUS_OVF_Msk    (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_STATUS_OVF_Pos)
comment.body: You can also move them to the `.c` file if that's the only place where they are used.

pull_request.title: drivers/include/periph: add FREQM peripheral driver
pull_request.body:
### Contribution description

This PR adds a peripheral driver for frequency meter (FREQM). Tested with SAM E54 XPLAINED PRO EVALUATION KIT (ATSAME54P20A microcontroller).

I think I have access to some other boards to test the driver in the near future.


<!--
Put here the description of your contribution:
- describe which part(s) of RIOT is (are) involved
- if it's a bug fix, describe the bug that it solves and how it is solved
- you can also give more information to reviewers about how to test your changes
-->


### Testing procedure
As the FREQM needs a reference clock to measure the frequency of another clock this test uses two internal clocks. The slower internal clock is used as reference to measure the faster internal clock.

The test can be invoked with:

    make -C tests/periph/freqm flash

Expected result (via serial):

    main(): This is RIOT! (Version: <INSERT VERSION HERE>)
    FREQM peripheral driver test
    Measured Clock Frequency: <MEASURED CLOCK FREQUENCY> Hz

<!--
Details steps to test your contribution:
- which test/example to compile for which board and is there a 'test' command
- how to know that it was not working/available in master
- the expected success test output
-->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,149 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @ingroup     cpu_sam0_common
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph_freqm
+ * @{
+ *
+ * @file
+ * @brief       Frequency meter driver implementation
+ *
+ * @author      Urs Gompper <urs.gompper@ml-pa.com>
+ *
+ * @}
+ */
+
+#include "periph/freqm.h"
+
+static void _freqm_clock_init(uint8_t msr_clk_src, uint8_t ref_clk_src)
+{
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_MSR */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(msr_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
+
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_REF */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(ref_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
comment.body:
> Do you remember what was the issue?

Microchip decided to rename all the structs and members, causing a lot of busywork if we ever want to support a new device again :weary:

comment.body:
> If the callback is only for the done interrupt, there are better ways to handle that than making it the API user's problem:
> 
>    * if the measurement time is really short, it's fine to busy wait on the `DONE` flag.
> 
>    * if the measurement may take some time, better make the function block by doing a `mutex_lock(&sync_lock);` after starting the measurement. The interrupt handler will then do a `mutex_unlock(&sync_lock);`

I'm fine doing either, just have a hard time determining what *really short* is. The fact that one can drive both clocks from I/O Pins (with possibly really slow clocks) makes me realize that hypothetically this can take some time. So I guess the mutex-solution it is.

> If you want periodic measurements, a callback handler that gets called each time a measurement is ready would be handy though. (But I'd still like to have a separate function for simple one-shot measurements)

Agree

comment.body:
The `minmea_getdatetime()` does just fill the `struct tm`, so there should be no problem if we exclude that. [see](https://github.com/kosma/minmea/blob/e368d847d75abd891c651f7d30ce5efb6681adb7/minmea.c#L641)

There is also the `minmea_gettime()` this also uses `timegm()` but I think we can only test that on native. [see](https://github.com/kosma/minmea/blob/e368d847d75abd891c651f7d30ce5efb6681adb7/minmea.c#L663)

pull_request.title: tests/pkg/minmea: fixing RMC timestamp
pull_request.body:
The RMC timestamp calculation was creating issues. The timestamp will be related to the EPOCH and time zone. Test on native will fail if the time zone is not set correctly. (see #20005)

# how to test

```
TZ=GMT-1 make test
```
 and 
```
TZ=GMT make test
```
and 
```
TZ=<any> make test
```

`timedatectl  list-timezones` provides you with a List of timzones 

do not fail

repo.name: RIOT
repo.description: RIOT -  The friendly OS for IoT

license.name: GNU Lesser General Public License v2.1

comment.body: `timegm` is not supported by the MCUs. I just remove the timestamp generation and we are just checking the raw time values here. The only function that is not checked here is `minmea_getdatetime()`.

pull_request.title: tests/pkg/minmea: fixing RMC timestamp
pull_request.body:
The RMC timestamp calculation was creating issues. The timestamp will be related to the EPOCH and time zone. Test on native will fail if the time zone is not set correctly. (see #20005)

# how to test

```
TZ=GMT-1 make test
```
 and 
```
TZ=GMT make test
```
and 
```
TZ=<any> make test
```

`timedatectl  list-timezones` provides you with a List of timzones 

do not fail

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,149 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @ingroup     cpu_sam0_common
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph_freqm
+ * @{
+ *
+ * @file
+ * @brief       Frequency meter driver implementation
+ *
+ * @author      Urs Gompper <urs.gompper@ml-pa.com>
+ *
+ * @}
+ */
+
+#include "periph/freqm.h"
+
+static void _freqm_clock_init(uint8_t msr_clk_src, uint8_t ref_clk_src)
+{
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_MSR */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(msr_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
+
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_REF */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(ref_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
comment.body:
Then it's fine to move these defines outside the driver scope as they are hardware-related.
@benpicco I remember vaguely a discussion about updating SAM0 vendor files a few months ago but there was an issue. Do you remember what was the issue ?

pull_request.title: drivers/include/periph: add FREQM peripheral driver
pull_request.body:
### Contribution description

This PR adds a peripheral driver for frequency meter (FREQM). Tested with SAM E54 XPLAINED PRO EVALUATION KIT (ATSAME54P20A microcontroller).

I think I have access to some other boards to test the driver in the near future.


<!--
Put here the description of your contribution:
- describe which part(s) of RIOT is (are) involved
- if it's a bug fix, describe the bug that it solves and how it is solved
- you can also give more information to reviewers about how to test your changes
-->


### Testing procedure
As the FREQM needs a reference clock to measure the frequency of another clock this test uses two internal clocks. The slower internal clock is used as reference to measure the faster internal clock.

The test can be invoked with:

    make -C tests/periph/freqm flash

Expected result (via serial):

    main(): This is RIOT! (Version: <INSERT VERSION HERE>)
    FREQM peripheral driver test
    Measured Clock Frequency: <MEASURED CLOCK FREQUENCY> Hz

<!--
Details steps to test your contribution:
- which test/example to compile for which board and is there a 'test' command
- how to know that it was not working/available in master
- the expected success test output
-->

labels.name: Platform: ARM
labels.description: Platform: This PR/issue effects ARM-based platforms

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @defgroup    drivers_periph_freqm FREQM
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph
+ * @brief       FREQM peripheral driver interface
+ *
+ * This interface allows to configure and use the for Frequency Meter (FREQM)
+ * available on some Microchip Boards.
+ *
+ * The Frequency Meter uses the frequency of a known reference clock to
+ * determine with a 24-bit accuracy the frequency of another clock.
+ *
+ *
+ * @{
+ *
+ * @file
+ * @brief       FREQM peripheral driver interface definitions
+ *
+ * @author      Urs Gompper <urs.gompper@ml-pa.com>
+ */
+
+#ifndef PERIPH_FREQM_H
+#define PERIPH_FREQM_H
+
+#include "periph_cpu.h"
+
+/* Channel Enable Mask */
+#define GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Pos)
+/* Enable Mask */
+#define FREQM_CTRLA_ENABLE_Msk  (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_CTRLA_ENABLE_Pos)
+/* Start Measurement Mask */
+#define FREQM_CTRLB_START_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_CTRLB_START_Pos)
+/* Measurement Done Interrupt Enable Mask */
+#define FREQM_INTENSET_DONE_Msk (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_INTENSET_DONE_Pos)
+/* Measurement Done Mask */
+#define FREQM_INTFLAG_DONE_Msk  (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_INTFLAG_DONE_Pos)
+/* FREQM Status Mask */
+#define FREQM_STATUS_BUSY_Msk   (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_STATUS_BUSY_Pos)
+/* Sticky Count Value Overflow Mask */
+#define FREQM_STATUS_OVF_Msk    (_U_(0x1) << FREQM_STATUS_OVF_Pos)
+
+
+typedef void (*freqm_callback_t)(uintptr_t context);
+
+/**
+ * @brief   Frequency meter configuration
+ *
+ */
+struct freqm_config {
+    uint8_t msr_clk_src;    /* GCLK source select for measurement */
+    uint8_t ref_clk_src;    /* GCLK source select for reference */
+    uint8_t ref_clk_cnt;    /* Measurement duration in number of reference clock cycles */
+    uint32_t ref_clk_freq;  /* Frequency of reference clock */
+};
+
+/**
+ * @brief   Start frequency measurement
+ *
+ * @return                  true if measurement started successfully
+ * @return                  false if frequency measurement is already ongoing
+ */
+bool freqm_start(void);
+
+/**
+ * @brief   Check if an overflow condition occured
+ *
+ * In case of an overflow condition either the number of reference clock cycles
+ * must be reduced or a faster reference clock must be configured.
+ *
+ * @return                  0 if no overflow occured
+ * @return                  1 if an overflow occured
+ */
+int freqm_error_get(void);
+
+/**
+ * @brief   Read number of periods of measured clock and calculate frequency
+ *
+ * @param[in] config        configuration
+ *
+ * @return                  calculated frequency
+ */
+uint32_t freqm_frequency_get(struct freqm_config *const config);
+
+/**
+ * @brief   Query if a frequency measurement is ongoing
+ *
+ * @return                  true if frequency measurement is ongoing
+ * @return                  false if there's no ongoing frequency measurement
+ */
+bool freqm_is_busy(void);
+
+/**
+ * @brief Register a callback function
+ *
+ * @param freqmCallback     callback function
+ * @param context
+ */
+void freqm_callback_register(freqm_callback_t freqmCallback, uintptr_t context);
comment.body:
> When is this callback called? (and why is `context` a `uintptr_t` instead of a `void *`?)

It's called when an interrupt occurs. Which happens when a measurement is finished.

As for `context` I wasn't sure how the user might use this and naively copied it from an example. `void *` sounds more reasonable, I agree.

pull_request.title: drivers/include/periph: add FREQM peripheral driver
pull_request.body:
### Contribution description

This PR adds a peripheral driver for frequency meter (FREQM). Tested with SAM E54 XPLAINED PRO EVALUATION KIT (ATSAME54P20A microcontroller).

I think I have access to some other boards to test the driver in the near future.


<!--
Put here the description of your contribution:
- describe which part(s) of RIOT is (are) involved
- if it's a bug fix, describe the bug that it solves and how it is solved
- you can also give more information to reviewers about how to test your changes
-->


### Testing procedure
As the FREQM needs a reference clock to measure the frequency of another clock this test uses two internal clocks. The slower internal clock is used as reference to measure the faster internal clock.

The test can be invoked with:

    make -C tests/periph/freqm flash

Expected result (via serial):

    main(): This is RIOT! (Version: <INSERT VERSION HERE>)
    FREQM peripheral driver test
    Measured Clock Frequency: <MEASURED CLOCK FREQUENCY> Hz

<!--
Details steps to test your contribution:
- which test/example to compile for which board and is there a 'test' command
- how to know that it was not working/available in master
- the expected success test output
-->

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,14 @@
+Peripheral FREQM Test Application
+=====================================
+
+This application tests the frequency meter (FREQM) functionality:
+
+- measuring the frequency of an internal clock with another internal clock as

comment.body:
> What prevent us from measuring an external clock ?

Nothing, I just wanted to make this test as simple as possible. Do you think a test-application for an external clock should be provided?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,121 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @defgroup    drivers_periph_freqm FREQM
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph
+ * @brief       FREQM peripheral driver interface
+ *
+ * This interface allows to configure and use the for Frequency Meter (FREQM)
+ * available on some Microchip Boards.

+ * determine with a 24-bit accuracy the frequency of another clock.
comment.body:
> Is this purely internal? I thought this was to measure the frequency of a signal on a GPIO.

It's not purely internal, the clocks can be driven by I/O pins. To claify this we could write something like
```suggestion
 * determine with a 24-bit accuracy the frequency of another clock.
 * These clocks can be driven by I/O pins.
```

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,149 @@
+/*
+ * Copyright (C) 2023 ML!PA Consulting GmbH
+ *
+ * This file is subject to the terms and conditions of the GNU Lesser
+ * General Public License v2.1. See the file LICENSE in the top level
+ * directory for more details.
+ */
+
+/**
+ * @ingroup     cpu_sam0_common
+ * @ingroup     drivers_periph_freqm
+ * @{
+ *
+ * @file
+ * @brief       Frequency meter driver implementation
+ *
+ * @author      Urs Gompper <urs.gompper@ml-pa.com>
+ *
+ * @}
+ */
+
+#include "periph/freqm.h"
+
+static void _freqm_clock_init(uint8_t msr_clk_src, uint8_t ref_clk_src)
+{
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_MSR */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(msr_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[5].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
+
+    /* Selection of the Generator and write Lock for FREQM_REF */
+    GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg = GCLK_PCHCTRL_GEN(ref_clk_src) | GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk;
+    /* Wait for synchronization */
+    while ((GCLK->PCHCTRL[6].reg & GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) != GCLK_PCHCTRL_CHEN_Msk) {}
comment.body:
> You should use vendor files defines like `FREQM_GCLK_ID_MSR`

This will work for `FREQM_GCLK_ID_MSR`, but unfortuenately `FREQM_GCLK_ID_REF` is not defined for samd51 and same54 devices, only for saml10 and saml11. They are defined in a newer version of the DFP as mentioned in https://github.com/RIOT-OS/RIOT/pull/20020#discussion_r1374057409

pull_request.body:
### Contribution description

This PR adds a peripheral driver for frequency meter (FREQM). Tested with SAM E54 XPLAINED PRO EVALUATION KIT (ATSAME54P20A microcontroller).

I think I have access to some other boards to test the driver in the near future.


<!--
Put here the description of your contribution:
- describe which part(s) of RIOT is (are) involved
- if it's a bug fix, describe the bug that it solves and how it is solved

-->


### Testing procedure
As the FREQM needs a reference clock to measure the frequency of another clock this test uses two internal clocks. The slower internal clock is used as reference to measure the faster internal clock.

The test can be invoked with:

    make -C tests/periph/freqm flash

Expected result (via serial):

    main(): This is RIOT! (Version: <INSERT VERSION HERE>)
    FREQM peripheral driver test
    Measured Clock Frequency: <MEASURED CLOCK FREQUENCY> Hz

pull_request.title: drivers/include/periph: add FREQM peripheral driver
pull_request.body:
### Contribution description

This PR adds a peripheral driver for frequency meter (FREQM). Tested with SAM E54 XPLAINED PRO EVALUATION KIT (ATSAME54P20A microcontroller).

I think I have access to some other boards to test the driver in the near future.


<!--
Put here the description of your contribution:
- describe which part(s) of RIOT is (are) involved
- if it's a bug fix, describe the bug that it solves and how it is solved
- you can also give more information to reviewers about how to test your changes
-->


### Testing procedure
As the FREQM needs a reference clock to measure the frequency of another clock this test uses two internal clocks. The slower internal clock is used as reference to measure the faster internal clock.

The test can be invoked with:

    make -C tests/periph/freqm flash

Expected result (via serial):

    main(): This is RIOT! (Version: <INSERT VERSION HERE>)
    FREQM peripheral driver test
    Measured Clock Frequency: <MEASURED CLOCK FREQUENCY> Hz

- the expected success test output
-->
